Name: Cobaltous nitrate
Description: Cobalt dinitrate is a cobalt salt in which the cobalt metal is in the +2 oxidation state and the counter-anion is nitrate. It is an inorganic nitrate salt and a cobalt salt. It contains a cobalt(2+).

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) NOAA; CAMEO Chemicals. Database of Hazardous Materials. Cobalt Nitrate (10141-05-6). Natl Ocean Atmos Admin, Off Resp Rest; NOAA Ocean Serv.
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: Food Chain Concentration Potential of Cobalt Nitrate Hexahydrate: Bioconcentration of 200-1000 fold only under constant exposure. Not significant in spill conditions(1).

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. V3 190
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ ... Depressing effect on blood pressure, observed when /cobaltous nitrate/ is given iv to mice ... .

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Dalhamn T; Acta Pharmacologica et Toxicologica 9 (3): 259-266 (1953)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ The median lethal dose (LD50) for subcutaneous administration of cobalt as cobalt-nitrate /to white mice/ was determined to be 34.6 mg/kg. After intraperitoneal injection of 40 mg/kg /dimercaprol/ (BAL), the LD50 of cobalt was 36.7 mg/kg. This difference was statistically significant. In cats and rabbits, the effects of cobalt on blood pressure and respiration rate are eliminated by intramuscular injection of BAL.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Van Campenhout E; Journal of Experimental Zoology 124: 535-559 (1955)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ After four daily injections of 0.03 g cobalt-nitrate, the pancreas /of guinea pigs/ showed an increase in number of endocrine islands. The majority of alpha cells were degranulated with nuclei surrounded by a colorless cytoplasm. When animals were allowed to recover after the last injection, islands returned to normal. Injections of colloidal cobalt produced a slight increase in number of endocrine islands. Alpha and beta cells were normal in size. After six daily injections, the pancreas showed a definite increase in number and size of islands. The author concludes that  cobalt-nitrate is identical in action to cobaltous-chloride but is far less toxic than  cobaltous-chloride.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Ivanchenko VA, AG Gizatullin; Aktual Vopr Allerg, Immun Zashch Mekh Org: 99-100 (1973)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Cobalt (as cobalt nitrate) admin SC to rats twice over 24 hr period incr erythropoietic activity of  the serum by greater than 3-fold, decr renal blood flow by 18%, and disrupted metab in kidney.

/LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ The acute toxicities of chloride, acetate, cobalt nitrate and cobalt sulfate (II) were investigated in rats. The values obtained for the LD50 (7 days) were 133, 194, 198 and 279 mg of Co/kg respectively, when the salts were given orally. The values for intraperitoneal administration were 10.6, 8.8, 8.3 and 11.5 mg of Co/kg. The majority of deaths occurred during the first 48 hours. The physical and clinical signs appearing after the intoxication disappeared for the most part after the first 72 hours ...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: International Program on Chemical Safety/European Commission; International Chemical Safety Card (ICSC) on Cobalt(II)nitrate (10141-05-6), ICSC No. 1397 (Peer Review Status: December 4, 2013, Validated). Available from, as of March 28, 2017: https://www.inchem.org/pages/icsc.html
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ ... Animal tests show that this substance possibly causes toxicity to ... reproduction or development.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: HHS/ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for Cobalt p.80-1 PB2004-10733 (April 2004). Available from, as of March 28, 2017: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Neurotoxicity/ Several rodent studies have identified neurological effects following cobalt exposure. In Wistar rats, a single gavage dose of 4.25 mg cobalt/kg as cobalt chloride resulted in a moderate reduction in spontaneous activity, muscle tone, touch response, and respiration, while 19.4 mg cobalt/kg as cobalt sulfate caused a mild reduction the same parameters. In rats exposed to 4.96 mg cobalt/kg/day as cobalt chloride for 30 days in the drinking water, cobalt led to changes in sympathetically mediated contractile activity of isolated rat vas deferens. Rats exposed to 6.44 mg cobalt/kg/day as cobalt nitrate in the drinking water showed an increased sensitivity and decreased maximal response to a cholinergic agonist. In rats exposed to 20 mg cobalt/kg/day as cobalt chloride for 57 days in the drinking water, cobalt enhanced behavioral reactivity to stress (the animals were less likely to descend from a safe platform to an electrified grid). Rats exposed to the same dose in the diet for 69 days showed a slower rate of lever pressing than controls, but no change in behavioral reactivity to stress. Longer-term exposure of rats to cobalt chloride (7 months) resulted in a significant increase in the latent reflex period at 0.5 mg cobalt/kg /and greater/ as cobalt chloride and a pronounced neurotropic effect (disturbed conditioned reflexes) at 2.5 mg cobalt/kg.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Prager, J.C. Environmental Contaminant Reference Databook Volume 1. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1995., p. 505
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ Allergen-skin; inhibits glucose oxidation.
